Sequence of the marriage as defined by the time stamp and other identifiers.

Location of the event of marriage, it is not necessary to define a sequence because this is already defined by having equal values in the timestamp. It is preferable to use a reference key to the context table and to enter the lowest level of the context
Last name or family name of the individual (this name may change during the life course, an empty timestamp means that no change took place).
Prefix of familyname, in Dutch context usually and in Belgian Context quite often seperated from 'main familyname', like 'De Boer'

First name of the individual. If the name consists of several parts, these parts must be separated by one space (charactar), (this name may change during the life course, an empty timestamp means that no change took place).
Title of noble origin like 'Baron', 'Duke' or another origin like 'Gentleman'
Standardized version of title

Age in years at a certain point in time handled by the time stamp, this variable exclude the use of other variables starting with 'AGE_' (for the same individual).

Period of observation, there may be separate periods of observation
Location or country from where a person enters the observation. It is preferable to use a reference key to the context table and to enter the lowest level of the context.
Location or country to where a person leaves the observation. It is preferable to use a reference key to the context table and to enter the lowest level of the context.

Only one variable in this table: the relationship from the first individual to the second one ; In case of biological relationships a timestamp is not necessary
Although, relations on siblings can be deducted from Father/mother and child relationships, information on these relations is not always available

In some contexts only one relationship with a father or a mother is avaible (in case of population registers the relationship with the father as householder is clear but it is not clear if the wife of the householder is also the mother).
Relationship defined by a birth certificate, timestamp is date of certificate [Birth, not present itself at the moment of notifying!]
Relationship defined by a death certificate, timestamp is date of certificate [Death, not present itself at the moment of notifying!]

Latitude giving the X- part of the coordinates for a Centroid (East West)
Longitude giving the Y-part of the coordinates for a Centroid (North South)

Extension to the number of the house
Name of the (house) boat where people are living
Name of the street or quay where a house boat is situated

Name of the landlord if not included in the IDS itself
Type of date
Date of an event, observed at the moment of the event itself (like the date of birth in a birth certificate)
Date of an event, reported in a later source (like the date of birth in a population register)
Date at which point in time a certain attribute is valid (like 'married' or some occupational title)
Date or period assigned by the database administrator
Type of estimation of date
Exact date (day, month and year)
Exact month and year  (no day-number), no estimation made of the day-number
Exact year  (no day- and month-number), no estimation made of the day- and month-number
The date is estimated
The date is estimated, xx gives the code of estimation
Begin and end of the period is estimated, xx / yy gives the code of estimation of start and end date
The start of the period is estimated, xx gives the code of estimation
The end of the period is estimated, xx gives the code of estimation
Reason why a (part of a) date is missing (and had to be estimated)
An (exact) date is missing in the source
An (exact) date is unreadable in the source
An (exact) date is available in the database but for reasons of privacy not included in the IDS
No date is necessary, e.g. in case of the variable SEX
An (exact) date has never been entered into the database for reasons of privacy
An (exact) date is missing in the source for reasons unknown (or not documented)
HSN identifying key of the original Research Person
HSN code to distinguish the Research Person (RP) from other persons
The individual is the HSN Research Person
The individual is the father of the HSN Research Person
The individual is the mother of the HSN Research Person
The individual has another relationship with the HSN Research Person
Indicates whether the child is delivered by a trained midwife.
The child is delivered with help from an untrained assistant.

Date of funeral; the value and further definition will be handled by the time stamp.
Legitimacy
Born outside of marriage, within betrothal
Born outside of marriage
Born within marriage
Recognized by father at birth
Legitimized by marriage of father and mother
No note on legitimacy. Children with unknown legitimacy are usually born within marriage.
Multiple birth.
N= number of births. For example 2=twins, 1=singleton, 3=triplets, etc.
Unknown information signify no multiple birth
Vaccination (smallpox).
These markers state that the persons have been infected from an ordinary smallpox infection. The given immunity made later attempts to vaccinate (or inoculate) them impossible.

The code includes markers that in a contradictory way state that the person has had both a natural smallpox and has been vaccinated. This is normally not possible. For persons born during the eighteenth century the marker ought to indicate natural smallpo
The markers show that the person is not immune against smallpox, i. e. either previously vaccinated or infected from the disease.

This code includes markers that undoubtedly tell that the person is vaccinated, but also markers that indicate inoculation (variolisation). Persons born after 1801 have most probably been given a vaccination note, while those born earlier might have been
The markers state that the person has been vaccinated more than one time, i. e. is revaccinated. The code indicates the strongest level of immunity.
Location of the funeral. It is preferable to use a reference key to the context table and to enter the lowest level of the context
Reason and date of the start of an observation
Observation started because of an arrival in a register (context)
Observation started because of birth
Observation started because an individual is present from the start in a register (without being present in other foregoing registers, included in the database)
Reason and date of the end of an observation
Observation ended because of death
Observation ended because of a departure out of a register (context)
Observation ended because an individual is present at the closing of a register (without being present in other succeeding registers, included in teh database)
The relation 'relative' or 'non-relative' is directed to the householder  (in relationship with the CONTEXT)
Person arrived in the register but reason is not specified and could not be deducted from other data
Person departed from the register but reason is not specified and could not be deducted from other data
Second part of original ccupational title with two titles (having exactly the same timestamp as the first title)
Second part of standardized ccupational title with two titles (having exactly the same timestamp as the first title)
Second part of English version of standardized ccupational title with two titles (having exactly the same timestamp as the first title)

HISCO_code for traded products present in second part of (standardized) occupational title like ores and minerals, textiles.
Third part of original ccupational title with three titles (having exactly the same timestamp as the first title)

Third part of English version of standardized ccupational title with three titles (having exactly the same timestamp as the first title)
HISCO_code of third part of standardized occupational title with three titles (having exactly the same timestamp as the first title)

HISCO_code for relationship with others' occupations or former occupations present in third part of (standardized) occupational title like daughter (of farmer), retired (merchant).
